text: A garbage truck roars by and... Simon Grim hangs from the back of it. He is a shy, skinny and terrified-looking guy around thirty years old. The truck rumbles to a halt and Simon climbs down off it go punch out at the time clock.

Moments later. He comes walking up a small alley and sits to drink his b He begins to relax. This is his quality private time. Then he hears something and looks up. He peeks up over the edge of some junked kitchen applianc and sees... Two teenage kids -- Warren and Amy -- smoking crack and h sex. Simon looks on, intrigued, as Warren smokes, then...
(to Amy) You want some?

Amy takes the pipe and smokes as he feels her up. Simon is fascinated. He drinks and looks on as... Amy grins up foolishly at Warren and lowers the pipe. The boy undoes his belt and hikes up the girl's skirt. Simon can't believe this. He looks around to see if the c is clear, then returns just in time to see... Warren takes Amy by the waist and enter her. The pipe falls from the young girl's hand. Warren throws his head back and grinds himself into her. Simon's mouth falls open in awe. But Amy tosses her head back to the side and sees... The amazed garbage man; caught. Amy starts screaming insanely. Simon runs for his life. Amy and Warren throw rocks and bottles at him as they cha him away.

Moments later. Simon runs up and throws open the screen door. He stands  there in the doorway catching his breath. His sister, Fay, is at the kitchen table watching a small portable TV while their mother, Mary, sits a few feet awa in the living-room watching another TV tuned to a differe channel.
(to Simon) Where the hell have you been? (to Mary) Mom, come on and eat.
I'm not hungry.
(pissed) Then why'd I cook!
Mary is a manic-depressive, still in her bathrobe at six the evening.
I don't know why you cooked! I don't  know why you bother!
Fay holds her head in her hands and sighs. She glares at brother.
Sit down and eat, Simon.

Simon sits at the table and Fay slams down before him a b of some sort of gruel. He hesitates, then lifts his spoon Supper is horrible and he screws up his face in disgust. gives him a sideways glance and he leans back down over t bowl and eats some more. Pushing the bowl away gently, he reaches out for the cont of milk on the table and drinks straight from it. He suddenly jumps back and spits out sour milk all over t table. The container drops to the floor and thick globs o cheese roll out. He stands back against the fridge, holding his stomach  while... Fay and Mary look on in disgust.

Moments later. Simon crosses the lawn and sits on the curb outside his h He stares at the ground before him as he holds his stomac and spits, sickened. He looks up, though, and sees... A little seven-year-old girl -- Pearl age seven -- standi there in the street watching him. Simon tries to smile at her. But she throws a rock at him and hits him in the head. He falls forward, hurt, as the little girl runs away. Low his hand, he sees he's bleeding. Desperate, lonely and il he drags his bloodied fingers across the coarse pavement. Fay slams out of the side door of the house in a tight-fi dress and stands on the lawn, applying lipstick.
God, I wanna get fucked.
Fay snaps shut her compact, straightens her skirt and sig
You OK?
Simon loses track of what he is hearing and relaxes. He l back at his sister. Fay fluffs out her hair and walks off.
See ya later.

Simon watches her go, but is still drawn to something he  seems to hear up the street in the other direction. He co his head, sits perfectly still and listens. He hears it now. We do, too. Footsteps. Big ones. Like a  giant somewhere in the distance. The neighborhood tremble Titles begin. Simon tries to figure out where it's coming from; the sky the house, the highway at the end of his block... Finally he focuses on... The blacktop right before him, smeared with his own blood Music starts. He kneels out slowly into the street and stares at the  pavement. He stretches out his hand and places it flat on the road. The pounding is louder now, becoming the beat o the music over the scene. Simon lowers his face to the pavement, closes his eyes an Puts his ear right down against the road. He hears... The steady tread of somebody very much larger than life. Kneeling forward, with his ear to the ground, Simon opens his eyes and sees... A man approaching. The music swells up full. Simon lifts his head slowly from the road, looking off in wonder at... This stranger coming towards him; an oddly handsome freak striding over the crest of the distant intersection with windswept mane, two over-stuffed suitcases and a crumpled tie fluttering back over his broad but crooked shoulders. Simon rises till he's kneeling up straight in the road. Henry Fool finally reaches him and stops. Titles finish. Simon says nothing and watches as Henry looks off at the  house. Satisfied, but wary, Henry Fool looks around the neighbor and then down at Simon.
Get up off your knees.
He tosses the suitcases down in front of Simon and walks towards his new home.
Henry comes around behind the house and finds the door to his basement apartment. He approaches. Simon follows, car the suitcases.

Moments later. The door is wrenched open and Henry is hit square in the by a decade of dank airless gloom. He coughs. Entering, he finds a few old wooden chairs littering the  main room. He inspects the old wood stove, then takes a c and smashes it. He tosses the wood in the stove. Simon looks on, amazed. Henry lights a fire with unusuall quick results, then stands back and looks at Simon.
Where you gotta go to get a six-pack  of beer around here?

This is a convenience store with a number of tables at wh to eat donuts. Warren is shoplifting while Amy terrorizes Gnoc Deng, the Vietnamese cashier, who stares out at them from behind th safety of the counter.
Say something.
(calling) She's mute.
What?
She don't -- you know -- talk.

Amy looks back at Gnoc, snarls, then follows the cashier' gaze to the door. Simon enters. Clutching Henry's cash, he stops dead in hi tracks when he sees... Warren and Amy. He steps forward and approaches the beer cooler. Warren and Amy hover around, just out of reach, like a co of vampires. Dragging a six-pack out of the cooler, Simon crosses to t counter. Warren and Amy hang back, silent and threatening Gnoc rings up the purchase and glances over at... Amy, staring a hole into the side of Simon's skull. Gnoc hands Simon back his change and he makes for the doo but... Warren shoves himself between it and Simon. Simon freezes. Warren is expressionless. Simon looks back Amy. She turns away, reaches up under her skirt, jerks do her panties, then leans forward on to the counter. Leerin back over her shoulder, she hisses...
Kiss my ass.

Simon is nonplussed. Gnoc presses a button on the wall that sets... A red light flashing above the stockroom door. Warren grabs Simon by the neck and drags him over to Amy' bare behind. Amy laughs as Simon is forced to his knees a has his face shoved up right into the crack of her ass. But then... Simon throws up all over her. Warren falls back in disgust. Gnoc covers her face with her hands. Amy looks around at herself, realizes, and starts screami bloody murder. Simon falls back on to the floor, clutching his stomach, Amy staggers around with her vomit-strewn underwear down  around her ankles. Then Gnoc's father, Mr Deng, appears at the stockroom doo holding a shovel and ready to fight.
(scared) Oh, shit!
Mr Deng comes running at them and Warren drags Amy from t store. Simon crawls out of the way as the old man throws  open the door to the parking lot and screams at the retre delinquents...
(in Vietnamese) Stay the hell out of my store, you  good-for-nothing punks!
Having scared them off, he comes back in and starts screa at Simon.
Look at this! What's going on here?  Simon, get up off the floor! Is this  beer paid for?

Later. Simon splashes water over his face at the kitchen sink, t watches as Henry unpacks one of his suitcases. It is fill with dozens of old, worn notebooks. Henry stacks them on mantelpiece over the fireplace; the fire is now crackling and bright. Simon steps over and looks at... The name tag on the other suitcase: 'Henry Fool'.
(off-screen) Centuries ago it had an 'e' at the  end.

Simon looks over and sees... Henry's silhouette against the fire. He steps forward int the light and grabs a beer from the six-pack on the floor He hands one to Simon. Simon takes it and stares at it a moment before raising h eyes to Henry.
Where do you come from?
Nowhere in particular.
He winks at Simon, then struts around the room, hugely  impressed with himself.
I go where I will and I do what I  must. (stops, drinks) That's why I'm in trouble. I'm sort've  what you might call... 'in exile'.
Why are you in trouble?
(stopping) An honest man is always in trouble,  Simon. Remember that.
Simon comes away from the fire, watching him carefully. H stands in a dim corner across the room.
How do you know my name?

Henry pauses, looks aside, drinks, then grins demoniacall He steps forward and comes face to face with Simon. He li his finger and points to... Simon's name stitched upon the breast of his work shirt. Realizing this, Simon moves off and thinks. Henry throws more wood on the fire, glancing back over hi shoulder, laughing mischievously.
(stopping him) I am not retarded.
(pauses) Well... I'll take your word for that.
(explaining) People. I mean. They think. You know.  Because.
He tries to articulate what he thinks he feels but winds gesticulating curiously with his hands. This finally diss into a dumb stare into empty space.
I see.
Simon looks at him. Henry stands and grabs a notebook fro off the mantelpiece. He tears out a few pages and shoves  them in his pocket. He hands the now fresh writing tablet Simon.
Here. Take this. And...
He searches his pockets and finds a pencil.
...this. Keep them with you at all  times. You ever feel like you got  something to say and you can't get  it out, stop and write it down. OK?
Simon hesitates, then accepts the gifts. Henry goes for  another beer while his new friend studies the dozens of  notebooks on the mantelpiece.
What are these?
(proudly, returning) This? This is my life's work. My  memoirs. My 'Confession'.
(carefully) What have you done?
Henry drinks and looks down into the raging fire.

(wistfully) I've been bad. Repeatedly. (shrugs and steps  away) But why brag? The details of my  exploits are only a pretext for a  far more expansive consideration of  general truths. (contemplating the  notebooks) What is this? It's a philosophy. A  poetics. A politics, if you will. A  literature of protest. A novel of  ideas. A pornographic magazine of  truly comic-book proportions. It is,  in the end, whatever the hell I want  it to be. And when I'm through with  it, it's gunna blow a hole this wide  straight through the world's own  idea of itself!
He smokes. Simon is impressed. They hear a bottle smash  outside in the street and Henry goes to the window. They' throwing bottles at the house.
(throwing down his  cigarette) Come on, let's go break their arms!
Simon jumps up.
No!
Henry stops. Simon looks away and sits back down.
(pauses) If I'm quiet.

He is ashamed of himself. Henry sees this and settles down. He considers his new fr with genuine care as he gets himself a new cigarette. He  lights up, thinks, then grabs another chair and sits clos by Simon. They sit there in silence a while, then...

Once. I forget where I was. Central  America maybe. Somewhere hot. Stupid  job. Bad pay. Dangerous location and  water so foul the natives wouldn't  even piss in it. This crowd of drunken  motherfuckers hired by the local  drug cartel shows up at my hotel  room and threatens to tear me limb  from limb. And I say, listen, hombres,  OK, you've got me outnumbered four  to one and you're gunna kill me here  tonight and not a soul in this dimly  lit world is ever gunna notice I'm  gone. Fine. But one of you... one of  you... one of you is gunna have his  eye torn out. Period. Silence. I  repeat myself. One of you poor,  underpaid jerks is gunna have an eye  ripped out of its socket. I promise.  It's a small thing, perhaps, all  things considered. But I will succeed.  Because it's the only thing I have  left to do in this world. So why  don't you just take a good look at  one another one last time and think  it over for a few minutes more. (smokes, waits) They sober up a little, look at their  shoes in confusion, then step out  into the hall to talk among  themselves.
Henry stares into the flames and falls silent. Simon is  riveted. He leans forward, on the edge of his seat...
What happened?
(winking) Well, here I am, still, after all.
Later that night. Simon climbs the stairs and stops when he hears raunchy s from his sister's room. He stands outside her door and  listens.
(off) Did you throw up all over some girl?
Simon looks up the hall and sees his mother in her room,  sitting on the edge of her bed, smoking. He approaches an stands in her doorway.
They were throwing bottles at the  house.
Simon says nothing. He looks down at his feet.
(gesturing to Fay's  room) She's got some ex-con in there she  met at the bar. Tattoos all over  himself and a big red bloated nose.
Did you take your pills?

Now she says nothing. She smokes and looks away. Simon steps into the bathroom and gets her medication. He runs a glass of water and brings it in to her. She swallows the pills and washes them back with water.
You want me to tell her to be quiet?
She looks away, unconcerned and cynical.
What's the use? She might as well  get it while she can. She's not always  gunna have the ass she has now, you  know. That's just how life is.
She throws the blanket over herself and turns off the lig Simon stands there in the dark.

Moments later. Simon comes downstairs into the quiet, dark kitchen and s at the table. He listens to the traffic on the highway an stares off into space. Finally, he takes the notebook Hen gave him from his pocket and places it before him. But th he just gazes off into the dim living-room and scratches head. Returning his attention to the notebook, he digs do into his pocket and retrieves his short stub of pencil. He opens the notebook and carefully flattens back the cov Lifting the pencil, he pauses and stares at the blank pag Then, after more intense hesitation, he brings the pencil dull tip to the very top left edge of the page and begins writing in a slow, laborious hand.
The next morning. Henry barges in the kitchen door with two containers of c and some jelly donuts. Simon jumps up from where he sits  asleep over his notebook at the table.
Good morning, Simon! Glorious day,  huh? Here, have a donut. Can you  lend me twenty dollars?
Simon rubs the sleep from his eyes, blinks, disoriented a reaches for his wallet.
Thanks. Where's the library in the  scruffy little burgh?
(handing him cash) Down the highway about a mile and a  half and then make a left.
Excellent! I'm polishing up the final  chapters of my 'Confession' and I  need a reasonably well-stocked  reference section.
He lifts up Simon's notebook.
What's this?
Simon hesitates, shyly.
I thought. Um. I was. I wanted to.  Maybe.
He gives up, sighs and gazes at the floor. Henry flips th the book, impressed. It is full from cover to cover, ever page dense with Simon's cryptic scrawl. Henry frowns,  intrigued. Then...
Can I take this?
Simon looks up, terrified. But his friend puts him at eas
I'll correct the spelling.
Later that day. Simon finds a number of volumes of the classics while cru garbage.

That evening. Simon sits with his evening beer and his new collection o soiled classics. He cracks open a volume of Shakespeare a tries to read. It's an obvious struggle. He puts it aside and lifts up Wordsworth, studying its cover and the textu of the pages. A page flutters away and he climbs down to edge of a greasy puddle to retrieve it. It's now wet and  torn, so he flattens it out on the concrete and tries to it back into the book. He reads a little, furrowing his brow, then drinks. He bi his lip and tries again. He sits back, exhausted and thinks. He hears a twig snap looks back over his shoulder to see... Amy throws a bottle at his head. Smash!!!! He falls to the ground, blood streaming down hi neck. Warren runs over and grabs him by the shirt, lifting him of the puddle and smacking him in the head. Amy runs forward and waits with a rolled-up newspaper whi she sets aflame with her lighter. Warren punches Simon in the stomach and throws him to the ground, then unzips his fly and pisses on him. Amy watches, giggling excitedly, waving the flaming torch Simon crawls away and grabs hold of an old section of fen while Warren zips up and grabs the fire from Amy. Simon pulls himself to his knees, rests his face against rusted fence and gasps for breath. Warren waves the flami torch in his face.
(weakly, unheard) One of you is gunna lose an eye.
Amy comes nearer with a can of gasoline. Simon pulls hims to his feet as she splashes him with fuel. Warren is wavi the torch deliriously above his head.
(screaming) One of you is gunna lose an eye!
Warren stops. Amy steps back and lowers the gas can. Simon turns with effort to face them, adjusts his glasses and continues...
One of you. I promise.

Warren watches him blankly, then is burned by the torch w is too hot to handle. He drops it. Amy giggles, then stops, excited, but confused. Simon grips the rusted chainlink so that it cuts into his hands and stares straight at Warren.
You can set me on fire. But one of  you is gunna have an eye torn out of  your head. I promise.

Warren is transfixed. He shivers and looks at Amy, who st back, scared, and puts down the gas can. She turns and wa away. Warren looks back at Simon, troubled. He hangs there still, glaring at him. Further away, Warren rejoins Amy and stares at his hands. Amy looks ill.
Fuck.
Take me home.

Henry is at one of the tables, correcting the spelling in Simon's notebook, when he looks up and sees... Simon stumble in, beaten and bruised, dropping his classi to the floor. Henry and Mr Deng rush over to him.
(scared) Simon! Who did this to you?
I was gunna tear out their eyes. I  knew I could do it.
Whose eyes?
I told them. Like you said. I told  them. And I knew I could do it.
He passes out. Henry looks at Mr Deng.
You should take him home. He smells  like a toilet.

Henry nods, agreeing, then lifts Simon off the floor. Mr  Deng holds the door open as Henry carries his friend out  into the parking lot. Meanwhile, Gnoc gathers up the classics from the floor an places them beside Simon's notebook, where it still sits  open on the table. She looks at it, then reads. She lifts off the table and reads further, immediately and deeply  engrossed. Mr Deng watches as Henry departs with Simon, then comes b into the store and stops, startled, when he sees... Gnoc sitting there, staring off into space, the notebook  open in her hands before her, singing quietly.
Twenty minutes later. Fay is in the bathroom helping Simon out of his clothes,  trying to clean his wounds.
(calling) Shit, Mom, we gotta get him to a  hospital!
No!
Oh, shut up! Turn around.
Henry is at the kitchen table with Mary. She watches him  suspiciously. He lets her.
This kinda thing has happened before.
(standing) It won't happen again.
She watches him as he walks around the room, browsing.
How do you know?
He stops and lifts a small framed photo of a soldier off piano.
This your husband?
Violated somehow, she gets up and snatches it out of his  hands. She puts it in a drawer and cringes as Henry plays one note on the piano.
Stop that.

He fixes her with a steady, knowing stare which causes he to gather the collar of her bathrobe up around her neck. steps back, exposed, when there's a knock at the door. Th look over to see... Mr Deng enter with the notebook.
(nods to Mary, then) Mr Fool, what is this?
It's poetry.
Are you sure?
Henry comes over, takes the notebook from him and shoves in his pocket.
Of course I'm sure. I corrected the  spelling myself.
It made my daughter sing.
Yeah, well, you know -- that's what  poetry does.
But she has never spoken in her life.
Meanwhile, back in the bathroom...
Owww!!!
Keep still!
Let me do it!
(fed up) Fine! You do it, Simon! I don't care!
She storms out to the top of the stairs, cocks her hip an whines...
Mom! Simon's got a broken rib, his  shoulder's dislocated or something,  and he won't let me disinfect the  gash in his head!
Fay, just take him to the hospital,  will ya!
(stamping her foot) But he won't go!
(screaming) Simon Grim, you go to the hospital  with Fay right now, do hear me!

Simon reaches out and slams the bathroom door. Fay looks from the bathroom door down the stairs to Mary. Mary, her nerves rattled, glances over at Mr Deng, who tu and leaves the house. Henry lights a fresh cigarette, loosens his tie and heads upstairs.
A moment later. Henry throws open the door and enters. He steps over Simo who is on the floor, folded up against the toilet.
We gotta talk.
Henry sits on the edge of the bathtub and takes the noteb from his pocket.
What the hell were you trying to do  when you wrote this thing?
Simon just looks at him, not certain what he means.
Nothing.
Well, you know you wrote it in a  kind of iambic pentameter.
Iambic what?
Verse.
He scratches his chin and smokes.

Look, in my opinion, this is pretty  powerful stuff. Though your spelling  is Neanderthal, and your reasoning a  little naive, your instincts are  profound. But the whole thing needs  to be given a more cohesive shape.  It can be expanded. Followed through.  Unified. (smokes, then) You see what I'm getting at?
Simon just stares at him, overwhelmed. Henry drops the  notebook on the floor and points at it with his cigarette
Are you willing to commit yourself  to this? To really work on it? To  give it its due? In the face of  adversity and discouragement? To  rise to the challenge you yourself  have set?
Simon just blinks, looks away and wonders.
And don't gimme that wonderstruck  'I'm-only-a-humble-garbage-man'  bullshit, either.
It hurts to breathe.
(nodding) Of course it does.
Simon coughs and Henry leans back and smokes.
An hour later. Fay cringes outside Simon's room as Henry goes about sett her brother's arm.
Like this?
Yeah. No. OK?
Wait!
Don't move! Fuck. There.
Are you sure that's right?
Yes. Now shut up and lie back.
Simon does.
Is this gunna hurt?
Yes.
He pauses, then leans back.
You gunna be alright?
Simon nods and stares at the ceiling. Henry hands him a t
Here. Bite on this.
(spots blood on it) What's that?
(looking) It's blood. From your head. Lie back.  Shove that in your mouth and hold on  to something.

Simon bites down on the towel and grips the edge of the b with his free hand. Henry sits on his legs and gently rai the broken arm. Outside the door, Fay bites her knuckles. Further down th hall, Mary listens from her bedroom.
Okay. You ready?
Simon nods. Henry grabs hold of the arm, swallows and bra himself. Simon waits, then Henry tugs the arm straight.
Aaagghhh!!!!!!!
Fay turns and runs down the stairs. Mary backs away into room and shuts the door.

Later that night. Henry comes downstairs and stops, tired. Fay is sitting a the table with a bottle of gin and two glasses. She has d herself up a little and Henry likes what he sees. He look her over and she smiles. He sits. She pours. They drink.
So, do you have, like, you know, a  girlfriend, Henry?
No.
They drink again in silence. He lights her cigarette and  they watch each other closely. Finally, Fay leans on the  table and twirls a strand of her hair between her fingers
Do you find me attractive?
Yes, I do.
I look young for my age, don't I?
How old are you?
How old do you think I am?
You look young.
(playfully) How young?
I don't know. Young.
But how... I mean, do I look more  like twenty, or... you know, thirty?
He drinks and studies her. She presents her profile. Fina he leans back.
Thirty.
Fay jumps up, furious.
Listen, you geek, after a couple of  drinks plenty of people mistake me  for eighteen!
She grabs her bag and storms out of the house. Henry watc her go, then chuckles deviously and splashes himself anot drink.

Next morning. A thirty-year-old cocktail waitress named Vicky walks up stops when she sees... Warren, sitting back against the side of World of Donuts, smoking a joint and thinking about his future. She sighs and approaches.
Hey, Warren, are you a registered  voter?
Bug off, Vicky!
Unruffled, she hands him a flyer.
(reading) 'Saving America From Itself.' What  the fuck is this?
It's everything you need to know  about the upcoming elections and  congressman Owen Feer and all the  really good things he wants to do  for our country.
He tokes deeply, then...
Oh yeah, like what?
He wants to win back this country  for us Americans, Warren, and restore  some kind of cultural-moral standard  to our way of life.
Warren looks over the flyer, then reconsiders Vicky.
What time's your kid go off to school?
(carefully) Nine o'clock.
How about I come over and visit you  later?
Vicky sighs, troubled. She adjusts her waitress uniform a looks mildly offended.
Well, I don't know, Warren. I mean...
Warren gets up, too.
Come on. I mean it. I'm trying to  change.
Vicky is hard-pressed. She wants to believe him, but know better. She thinks about it while... Henry passes by and approaches the store.

Same time. Henry enters and takes Simon's notebook from his pocket. flips through a few pages and selects one in particular. He tears it out of the book and tapes it up beside the  register so customers can read it. He winks at Gnoc. She  smiles shyly and makes him a coffee. He takes it and move off to a table just as... Vicky enters. She starts accumulating groceries, placing  them on the counter one item at a time. Henry settles down and watches as... Vicky returns to the counter with a bottle of orange juic and notices the poem. She reads, holding the orange juice out to her side. Gnoc starts to ring up the other purchases as her father  comes up behind her, busying himself with an inventory of the cigarettes. Vicky's lip starts to tremble as she reads, a horrified  expression clouding her face. Finally... Smash!!!! She drops the bottle of orange juice and stands back. Mr Deng and Gnoc jump back, alarmed. Henry tilts his head and pays close attention.
(screaming at Mr Deng) How dare you put something like this  up where anyone can see it!
Mr Deng looks from her to the poem and then over at Henry Henry urges the man to stand up for himself.
(to Vicky) It's poetry.
It's pornography! The product of a  diseased mind! You oughta be ashamed  of yourself, Mr Deng!
It made Gnoc sing.
(pauses, confused) It's disgusting! There oughta be a  law or something!
She grabs her things and leaves. Mr Deng holds his head a looks over at Henry.
(winking) There's no accounting for taste, is  there, Mr Deng?
Mr Deng has no idea. He sits, worried, as Gnoc comes out  from behind the counter and begins mopping up the mess.
Later. Henry is at the kitchen table with Simon, working on the  poem. Simon is bandaged up, his arm in a sling, black eye etc.

See, Simon, there are three kinds of  there. There's 'There'. T-H-E-R-E.  There are the donuts. Then there's T- H-E-I-R; which is the possessive. It  is their donut. Then, finally, there's  'they're'. T-H-E-Y-'-R-E. A  contraction, meaning they are. They're  the donut people. Get it?
Uh-huh.
Henry lifts up one of Simon's newly acquired classics...

And look, if you're gunna read  Wordsworth you've gotta get a more  up-to-date edition. This odoriferous  tome you're so attached to doesn't  even have all fourteen books of the  Prelude. And you need notes.  Commentary. I'll go to the library  and find you the best edition they  have.
Thank you, but that's OK. I'll stop  there on my way back from work. Well,  yes, maybe not today, but, you know,  tomorrow, probably.
Quit.
My job?
Yeah.
Why?
You need time to write, Simon. To  study. To reflect.
But I like my job.

We all have to make sacrifices. A  vocation like ours, Simon, is not a  nine to five thing. You can't put a  fence around a man's soul. We think  and feel where and when we can think  and feel. We are the servants of our  muse and we toil where she commands.

Simon looks past him and Henry follows his gaze to find.. Mary standing at the foot of the stairs, listening to the She says nothing. She looks Henry up and down, then shake her head disdainfully and grunts. She throws herself on t couch and turns on the TV, casting acid glances over at t kitchen.
Moments later. Henry and Simon come outside...
She's clinically depressed.
Yeah, and what's that mean?
(thinking, then) I guess it means it's not her fault.
Henry wanders out to the road, checking his wallet, then.
(sighing) You ever think of leaving?
Here?
Yeah.
To go where?
Out there. You know, into the world.  Where ever.
Simon looks off, thinks it over and slowly nods.
Yeah, I guess.
(reciting) 'Opportunity will step away and make  room for a man to pass it by.'
Is that from your book?
No. I found it in a fortune cookie.
He pulls the tiny piece of crumpled advice out from one o his pockets and shows it to Simon.
Can I read your confession?
No. Not yet. Soon. We'll see.
Is it almost finished?
